markups: ''Games where gameplay is easy to begin, perform, pause, and end, without negatively affect any players' experience.''

Puzzle-based games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Combine">Combine</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Staries">Staries</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Keeper">Zoo Keeper</link></style> are examples of games with <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> simply because they either are played for a limited amount of time or because one can take pauses from them whenever one wishes. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style> shows how an action game can provide <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> as well due to the ease of beginning to play and the limited time of each game instance.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mafia%20Wars">Mafia Wars</link></style> are examples of <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> first based on the social site [http://www.facebook.com Facebook]. While players can require a lot of knowledge of how to play the games most effectively, they are easy to pick up and the gameplay allows players have control of when they wish to play - although social pressure to return favors to other players can offset the latter.
The instantiation of <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> depends on the combination of many independent design choices.

A first requirement is that players should be play sessions can be started or stopped without being too <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> or too much of a time or social commitment. This makes <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> well-suited to be be the carriers of <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style>, although the use of <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> show how games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mafia%20Wars">Mafia Wars</link></style> can be <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style>. Other solutions include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Gameplay%20Time">Limited Gameplay Time</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="negotiable-play-sessions">Negotiable Play Sessions</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> are a double-edged sword in this case; it limits the time commitment but increases <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> can of course also work for this, but this depends on the nature of the gameplay (e.g. level of <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>). Even if some games depict <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mafia%20Wars">Mafia Wars</link></style>), games aiming at <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> more often consists of <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> than <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> in order to avoid stressful gameplay. Related, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> they provide rarely allow <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> or put players in situations of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Inherent%20Mistrust">Inherent Mistrust</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>, instead using safe alternatives as for example <style="Link"><link="free-gift-inventories">Free Gift Inventories</link></style>.

A second requirement is that a game with <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> should be easy to take up, even from the start. This means providing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> and avoiding <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, which can be achieved through the help of <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> (either as <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>/<style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or as <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>) that explain new gameplay features as they appear. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> in games does not in itself make for <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style>, but can modulate it and support it indirectly through supporting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> and other <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> are a simple way of letting players have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> between a certain form of <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, as can <style="Link"><link="point-interest-indicators">Point of Interest Indicators</link></style>. If the <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> is to be enforced more, another option similar to <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> include using <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style>. As another example, <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> can be made easy initially through the use of <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style> and other support but these can latter be absent when players can be assumed to have mastered this activity in a game.

Although <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> needs to avoid <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> it does not need to avoid <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, since this can be introduced gradually from <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>. This shows one way <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> can be combined with <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> - for example knowing the most efficient ways of gaining resources given a particular style of play in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> - but it can also be through being able to perform relatively simple tasks many many times in a row (as in for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style>). The latter can be seen as an a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Time%20Investments">Player Time Investments</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style>, as can the way <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> is instantiated to support <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style>.

<style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can be suitable for providing <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> since they can both provide support for play sessions limited in time and be constructed to not be too difficult. For games using <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-reported-positioning">Self-Reported Positioning</link></style> lets players claim be in positions they are not and thereby free them to only move as much as they wish rather than what the physical distances actually demand.

One of the characteristics used to describe the difference between casual games and others is that they tend use positive colors and sounds in the presentation of their <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. Although this is primarily a question of graphic and sound design, it can also reflect the tendency to focus upon <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>.

The flexibility of when to start or stop playing makes games with <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> provide a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to players. The combination of this <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and often having <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> gameplay make players have the possibility to regard the gameplay of these games as <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style>.

Quite naturally, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> does not work together with <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style>, and as argued above with <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. Likewise, the possibility of <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> can be problematic since it makes gameplay depend on other players' behavior. Since <style="Link"><link="handicap-achievements">Handicap Achievements</link></style> typically make gameplay more challenging, these do not well with <style="CurrentLink">Casual Gameplay</style> either (although <style="Link"><link="grind-achievements">Grind Achievements</link></style> can do this).
